name: Moong Dal Paratha
ingredients: Aamchoor Powder (or Chaat Masala as an alternative)
Moong Dal (washed, soaked for 3-4 hours or overnight)
instructions: To make the dough, take flour in a bowl.
Add salt according to taste, a little black salt, and a little asafoetida for flavor.
Add finely chopped green chilli, finely chopped ginger, and a lot of green coriander.
Mix in coriander powder, red chilli powder, a little turmeric powder, and fennel seeds for flavor.
Add a little tanginess using aamchoor powder. If aamchoor powder is not available, use chaat masala as an alternative.
Optionally, add a little raw mustard oil for a sharp kick and nice aroma.
Add whole dry fenugreek leaves for flavor.
Soak the washed, skinless moong dal for 3-4 hours or overnight. Remove excess water from the soaked dal.
Add the soaked moong dal directly into the flour mixture. Do not add water yet.
Mix the dal with the flour. Add water little by little as needed to form a dough, as the dal already contains some water.
Knead the dough well. Cover it with a wet cloth and let it rest for 15-20 minutes.
After resting, divide the dough into small portions (pedas). The dough might be slightly sticky, which is normal.
While rolling, use a little dry flour to prevent sticking. Roll out the pedas into parathas. If shaping is difficult, use a plate to cut it into a round shape.
Heat a tawa (griddle) and place the rolled paratha on it. Cook one side lightly, then flip it.
Cook the other side lightly and flip again. Add a little oil or ghee to the paratha and roast it.
Flip and cook both sides well, pressing lightly to ensure even cooking. If not using oil or ghee, the paratha can be made dry and served with tea.
Cook on medium heat until the paratha is golden and crispy. Serve hot with butter, lassi, or the prepared Chilli Garlic Raita.

name: Chilli Garlic Raita
instructions: To prepare the raita, start by heating a little oil in a small pan.
Add dry red chilli to the hot oil and roast on medium flame until it puffs up, becomes crispy, and its color turns red.
Remove the roasted red chilli from the pan and set it aside to cool. Do not discard the remaining oil.
In the same oil, add finely chopped garlic. Keep the flame low and brown the garlic completely to enhance its flavor.
Once the garlic is browned, pour it directly onto the curd.
Coarsely crush the roasted red chilli using a mortar and pestle or similar tool.
Add the crushed red chilli to the curd along with regular raita ingredients: salt, black salt, roasted cumin powder, and finely chopped green coriander.
Mix everything well. The raita is ready with roasted garlic flavor and smoky chilli.
